subject: Gardening
title: Monocot vs. Dicot Seeds
description: A 60-second lesson on Monocot vs. Dicot Seeds.

hook.text: Split a bean and you see two halves. Split corn and you don't. That difference defines two plant kingdoms.

buildup.text: Dicots have two cotyledons (seed leaves)â€”beans, sunflowers, tomatoes. Monocots have oneâ€”grasses, lilies, orchids.

discovery.text: Cotyledons differ by group: in dicots, they store food directly. In monocots, they absorb it from the endosperm.

twist.text: This one structural difference predicts root type, leaf veins, flower shape, and stem growth for the whole plant.

climax.text: One vs. two seed leaves. From this tiny distinction, the entire architecture of a plant's life unfolds.

punchline.text: One seed leaf or two decides everything about a plant.

quiz.question: What does the number of cotyledons in a seed predict about the plant?
options: Only the size of the mature plant
Root type, leaf venation, flower structure, and stem growth pattern
Whether the plant will be edible or poisonous
